page.title: 04TRANSPORT IN SADDLEWORTH
page.content: 4 trans-Pennine routes originally crossed this area: 2 turnpike roads, the Huddersfield Canal and the Leeds- Stalybridge railway. Present main roads are to Huddersfield (A62) & Holmfirth (A635) both from Manchester. There is a bus service through Diggle village to Oldham. The Huddersfield Narrow Canal was the second navigational system to cross the Pennines and was completed in 1811 amidst great celebrations, but was officially abandoned in 1944 due to a decline in traffic. Conservation work is now in progress to restore it. The main railway line from Stalybridge to Huddersfield was opened in 1849 & a branch line carried passengers, called "Delph Donkey Line". There was once a station at Diggle, now closed, and the last passenger train ran in April 1955 so the main line now is freight only.
